DIV1.P: INSCRIBED TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE The EARL of GRANVILLE.

Q.L: When Violence was ceas'd, and War on Earth,
All would have then gone well, Peace would have crown'd
With Length of happy Days the Race of Man;
That we find out the Cause of this Effect,
Or rather say, the Cause of this Defect;
For this Effect defective comes by Cause.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for the Author, and sold by T. KINNERSLY, at the Paper-Mill, in St: Paul's Church-Yard; and by the Booksellers of London and Westminster.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE THE EARL of GRANVILLE.
DIV1.P:
WITH the greatest Humility and Submission, I solicit your Pardon for throwing my poetical Brat at your Lordship's Door. If my Presumption offend, I am truly sorry for my Fault; but, by Way of Excuse, must beg Leave to add, that no less illustrious a Personage, than the Earl of Granville, is partly accessary to the Crime: Had not your Lordship taken such uncommon Pains to distinguish your Benevolence to Man∣kind, and that inviolable Attachment to the BRITISH Constitu∣tion,
which is so eminently display'd in your truly-patriot Spirit; had not your Lordship so strenuously exerted those shining Abi∣lities, with which Nature hath blessed you, in the Preservation of the Liberties of your Fellow-Subjects, and so indefatigably en∣deavoured to restore the Glory of the BRITISH Name, I should not have singled out your Lordship for a Patron to this Philippic. Believe me, my Lord, when I assure you, if I had known one BRITON, to whom I could have more properly inscribed the following Piece, that I should not have troubled your Lordship with the present Address. I am,

CLOSER.SALUTE: My LORD, Your Lordship's most obedient, and devoted Servant, The AUTHOR.

LG.L: AT length 'tis done! The Dread, and the Desire
Of Albion's hapless Isle! The Brand of War
Is lighted to inspire Britannia's Sons
To Justice and Revenge on the proud Gaul.
Our ever-gentle Sov'reign, to preserve
A human Race from the Calamities
Of desolating War, hath long delay'd
His hostile Purpose, hopeful to procure
Redress for violated Rights by Means
More merciful, and mild; but what Redress
Can Gentleness, and meek Forbearance hope
From mad Ambition, and th' aspiring Pride
Of Bourbon's haughty Line?—And is it come
So soon to this? For this did Britain send
Her noble Hostages to faithless Shores?
Is this th' Event of our deluded Hopes,
And costly Preparations to proclaim
The terminated Havock, which of late
Wasted the warring Nations?—Hapless We!
Whose Habitation Providence assigns
Beneath that gentle Government, where Peace,
And the Protection of a People's Rights
Are all the Sov'reign's Care, to be reduc'd
To this last, worst Necessity, a War,
To vindicate our Wrongs! — Perfidious France!
Are these thy Treaties? These thy plighted Vows,
Unviolated, to preserve the Peace
Of ravag'd Empires? Must destructive War,
That hell-engender'd Monster, then resume
So soon, alas! so very soon resume
Her bloody Front, and Desolation thin
The slaughter'd World? — How will the tender Breast,
By kind Humanity's soft Feelings touch'd,
Bewail the sad Occasion, and deplore
That curs'd Ambition, and the giddy Pride
Of Princes should involve a human Race
In Massacre and Blood! — Fond Sighs, away!
The Die is thrown: Condolance and Complaint
Are fruitless now: It were a fitter Task
To warn my Countrymen from Danger's Path
By pointing out with Freedom, and bold Truth,
(My Birthright as a Briton, and a Bard)
Th' unhappy Sources of re-kindled War.
From whence proceeds this Gallic Insolence?
This Violation of the sacred Bonds,
Th monize the various Race of Man,
To kindle, unprovok'd, a Scene of Blood
In Columbian Territories? Whence
T numerous Insults on Britannia's Power,
Which make this languid Isle, the Terror once
Of an affrighted World, the Ridicule
Of distant Empires? Why hath faithless France,
This proud Disturber of the public Peace,
This restless Foe, so often and so long,
Practis'd, unpunish'd, her perfidious Cheats
On unrevenging Britain? Are we then
Become so passive, that insulting Gauls,
These meagre Sons of Slavery and Soup,
Deride our Flags? — And dare they to deride
A naval Force, superior to their own,
So far superior, that a British Cheek
Would redden at the wide Comparison?
Ask the proud Battlements in Dunkirk rais'd,
In UNDEMOLISH'D Dunkirk, they will tell
In what Contempt our dreadless Fleets are held,
While Luxury, and Avarice unman
The native Spirit of our little Isle.
Destructive Vices! From your baneful Spring
Flow all our national Complaints. By you
The Glory of Britannia's awful Name,
Which carried Terror to remotest Climes,
And froze the trembling Infidel beneath
The burning Line, is proverb'd into Shame.
What have our vaunted Expeditions been,
But the just Theme of Mockery, and of Scorn
Thro' every civiliz'd Dominion? Speak
Of gallant Hosier—what is the Reply?—
"This dauntless Man, whose Courage would have dar'd
"To storm the burning Battlements of Hell,
"Was sent inglorious from his native Land
"On a Parade of Conquest: but, alas!
"To his deluded Country and himself
"Unknown, a shackled and unwilling Slave
"To ministerial Mandates!" — Ask the Cause
Why private Feuds subvert the public Weal;
Why Matthews, obstinately brave, withstood
Th' unequal Shock of War, while his Compeer,
Revengeful, proud, and unassisting saw
A British Fleet endanger'd, shatter'd, torn
By Force superior—with contemptuous Sneer
The Foreigner rejoins, "Your virtuous, wise,
"And uncorrupted Statesmen"— but the rest
Be sunk in Silence: let me not recall
To your Remembrance, Britons, the Disgrace,
The rank Abuse your suffering Isle sustain'd:
Such Aggravation would but ill become
The Breast, that burns with Love of Liberty,
And British Glory: let me rather strive
To shake your sluggard Virtue from the Folds
Of this degenerate Luxury and Ease,
This dull Indifference to your Country's Fate,
And rouse you into Britons, into Men.
But how effect this wish'd, this great Event?
A deviated People how reclaim
To Virtue, Fortitude, and Glory? This
Were Happiness indeed! O for a Muse
Equal to such a Task! that I might fire
Britannia's free-born Sons to emulate
The great Atchievments of their warlike Sires;
To scourge those glaring Insults, they have prov'd
From this proud, false, encroaching, restless Gaul! —
Impracticable Wish! th' immortal Bard,
Who sightless sung, in never-dying Strains,
Revolted Angels, and fair Eden's Loss,
In vain would strike his Epic Lyre, to raise
Th' inactive Spirit of this drousy Isle
To that unconquerable Height, to which
Our venerable Ancestry aspir'd.
But are we plung'd in Luxury so deep,
That Reason's friendly Hand is stretch'd in vain
To snatch us from th' inextricable Lake?
We are: with Caution mark the general Run
Of Man, and Observation will confirm
The melancholy Truth—Mad Revelry,
And wild Profusion rage beneath the Roof,
Where Virtue, and Oeconomy adorn'd
The courteous Dwelling. Riot and Debauch
Have sunk the hardy Briton's manly Frame
To the lank Substance of the starvling Gaul:
His Mind, his Manners, with his Person share
The Change, and all his Dignity consists
In empty Title — View that medly Rout
Of Statesmen, Nobles, Sharpers, Patriots, Pimps,
At Arthur's in nocturnal Senate met—
See here the ruinous, and mad Effects
Of Luxury, Av'rice, and inglorious Ease,
That Curse of higher Life—Amid the Group
Mark that illustrious Bubble—This is He,
The very Man, whose powerful Eloquence
Enchants the listening Senates—this is He,
The very Briton, whose industrious Zeal
For Liberty o'er-turns th' oppressive Schemes
Of ministerial Hirelings—Heaven and Earth!
That one, whose patriot Vigilance secures
The public Weal, should thus neglect his own!
That one, whose vast Abilities would grace
Creation in a more exalted Sphere,
Should fink his noble Faculties in Sports
So dull, so tasteless, so irrational!
Alas! what Pity—but of this enough—
With general View survey the motley Throng,
And note the solemn Business of the Night—
Time-killing Whist her silent Votaries
Employs, and anxious Meditation sits
On every pensive Brow, revolving o'er
The Mazes of the Deal—the Game is done—
And now the cully'd Noble is involv'd
In Debts of Honour to a sharping Tribe,
Beyond the present Possibility
Of Payment—What's the necessary Mean
To set this honourable Madman free
From such Enthralment?—Are the Debts secur'd
By Mortgage? No; his prudent Ancestry
Intail'd the Manor—the rapacious Claims
Must still be satisfied, or Honour sinks
Beneath the Weight of Shame—the Scheme is hit—
Annuities are granted: he becomes
The nominal Possessor of his own,
And yearly parcels out to Rooks and Knaves
The stipulated Pensions—thus he toils;
Till, wearied of his Stewardship and Life,
He calls the friendly Bullet to his Aid,
And frees his clogg'd Possessions from the Claims
Of annual Cormorants, the prudent Mean
To save his Family from Want, and Shame.
But if, by Fears of endless Woe with-held
From Suicide, he drags the galling Chain
Of his Existence, what is to be done
His shatter'd Fortunes to repair? — The Bait
Is thrown; his Conscience struggles; but at length
Yields to Necessity's all-conquering Plea:
He catches at the golden Lure, and sells
His Country. Thus, in striving to avoid
The less, he meets the greater Ill, and draws
Inhanc'd Damnation on his guiltier Head.
Behold that mettled—what?—A Groom? Or Lord?—
Alternate both: How eagerly he pants
For hippdromic Glory! With what Joy
He hears th' applauding Shout, when Victory
On titled Rider, and swift-springing Steed
Confers the Honours of the struggled Race!
What can induce the Spark to study thus
The Pedigrees of Bajazets, and Barbs?
Science profound! and mingle with base Grooms,
The Scum, and Offal of a human Race?
What, but a mean, mistaken Love of Fame,
By Luxury begot, on thoughtless Minds? —
Infatuated Youth! were all those Hours,
So dully, so unprofitably spent,
Employ'd in canvassing thy Country's Laws;
Wer't thou as careful of Old England's Rights
And Liberties, as of thy dearer Stud,
Thy Name would live in History's fair Page,
When Pond's elaborate Chronicle hath slept
In dull Oblivion thro' many an Age.
Mark that effeminate, powder'd, frizzled Fop!
He went from hence a Briton, and return'd
A Monkey. What from Travel hath he gain'd?
The fashionable Folly to despise
His native Country—How the Changeling doats
On foreign Kickshaws, Trumperies, and Toys!
So fond of Paris, and the gilded Baits
Of Slavery, that he's an Englishman
In nothing but in Name. His Meat, his Drink,
His Dress, his Talk, his very Mind is French—
What Hoards of Treasure hath this tinsell'd Dupe
Most prodigally squander'd in his Tour,
On Dress, Whores, Dancers, Fidlers, Valets, Cheats,
Cards, Dice and Equipage! Should no Restraint
Be put on wasteful Youth to remedy
This rambling Madness in our Countrymen?
How many Millions hath this Folly cost
Impov'rish'd Britain! And how many more
Must follow, if the Frenzy be not crush'd
By legal Influence! Justly we complain
Of Gallia's growing Power—had we in time
Restrain'd our lavish Intercourse with France,
Discourag'd all her Manufactures, all
Her fashionable Baubles, and despis'd
The palatable Poison of her Vines,
Her scanty Coffers had not furnish'd out
A Fleet so formidable, that she seems
Intended with Old-England to dispute
Her immemorial Empire o'er the Main.
See that Assemblage of the Sons of Wealth,
Whose Pity and Humanity extend
To dumb Creation! With what costly Care
They study to preserve the brutal Race
From vulgar Persecution! Truly great
Were such Benevolence, could their design,
Deserve so laudable a Name! — Alas!
What are they but Monopolists in Blood,
That to themselves endeavour to preserve
Inviolate the cruel Privilege
Of Slaughter and Destruction? What is this
But petty Tyranny, th' ambitious Child
Of Luxury and Pride? If Heaven indulge
A Right to kill, each free-born Briton sure
May claim his Portion of the Carnage. All
O'er Nature's Commoners, by Nature's Law,
Plead equal Privilege: what then supports
This Usurpation in the wealthier Tribe;
The qualifying Acres? No, proud Man,
Possessions give not thee superior Claim
To that, which equally 'pertains to all—
Whose Property you timid Hare, which feeds
In thy Inclosure? Thine? Deny'd—Allow'd—
Yet if the fearful Animal be thine,
Because she innocently crops to-day
The Herbage of thy Freehold, whose will be
The Claim to-morrow, when thy Neighbour's Soil
Affords her Pasturage? — Assuming Man!
How is the hardy Briton's Spirit tam'd
By thy oppressive Pride! — When Danger comes,
Who shall defend thy Property? Thyself?
No; that poor Briton, whom thou hast undone
By Prosecutions—will he not retort,
"What's Liberty to me? 'Tis lost! 'Tis gone!
"If I must be oppress'd, it matters not
"Who are th' Oppressors. Shall I hazard Life
"For those imperious Lordlings, who deny'd
"That Privilege, which Heaven and Nature meant
"For Food, or Sport, or Exercise to all?"
Hath every British Bosom then receiv'd
The Taint of Luxury? I would not brand
The Natives of my Country with a Charge
So universal. Millions have escap'd
The pestilential Ruin; many more
Are pierc'd so slightly by its poisonous Sting,
That timely Application would remove
The Malady. Amid this spreading Ill
The glorious Spirit of our dauntless Tars
Remains yet uncorrupted. Britain still,
Tho' hopeless to regain by future Feats
Her pristine Glories in the Field, may rule
Unrival'd on the fluid Element.
But there, even there, she must not vainly hope
For uncontroul'd Dominion and Command,
Till happier Measures influence and crown
Her yet-successless Councils; till her Fleet
s freed from the right honourable Thrall
Of Cowards, petty Tyrants, Fops, and Fools:
Till unbefriended Merit wins the Prize
From suppliant Int'rest, and, the Bane of all,
Destructive Luxury shall quit her Shores.
Now is the Time, my Fellow-Britons, now
To rouse you from your Lethargy. Your All,
Your Liberty, your Country is at Stake;
And Glory calls you forth to signalize
The British Name; to punish the proud Gaul,
And free from Slavery th' endanger'd World.
The general Cause of Liberty depends
On British Valour, and a British Fleet,—
This conquer'd Isle facilitates the Way
To universal Empire—Such a Cause
Should fire your languid Virtue to Revenge,
And Conquest—Haste, my gallant Britons, haste
To scourge the faithless, enterprizing Foe—
Away with this impolitic Defect!
This Novelty in War, divided thus
To parcel out your widely-scatter'd Fleet
In scanty Destinations! — Mark the Tale
Of Rome's HORATIAN Contest—Rome had lost
The Glory, had the triple Foe assail'd
United her surviving Combatant—
Reason methinks would point a surer Path
To Conquest, and advise her British Sons,
With Fleets collected, suddenly to hurl
Their vengeful Thunders on the naval Hopes
Of France, and, by the timely Ruin, end
The future Horrors of protracted War.
